Award.AwardTitle: CCRI: Collaborative Research: Planning for World Of Code (WoC): An Infrastructure for Open Source Software Census

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
While software engineering research has made great progress over the decades, the unavailability of data has long been a major limitation. Open source software (OSS) makes large quantities of data available, creating the promise of using modern quantitative techniques on very large data sets to understand how to create better software and improve productivity. However, the data exists in different formats, has many errors and omissions, is located in millions of repositories around the world, and requires extensive processing to render it in a form researchers can use. The planning grant aims to develop the requirements for creating World of Code (WoC), an infrastructure for enhancing software engineering research, and to build a research community centered around massive data gathered from all open source repositories around the world. This planning process will ensure that WoC, if realized, will enable researchers to easily access all open source data, resolve issues of replication, avoid drawing samples that are not representative, and reduce the risk of inappropriate conclusions based on erroneous data. The planning grant will establish a Steering Committee and an Advisory Board to guide the development and evolution of the resource in a way that provides the greatest value to the community of researchers. Hackathons will give both experienced and novice researchers an opportunity to learn how to use WoC's prototype capabilities, add to the tooling, and concretely express the desires and priorities of the research community WoC seeks to serve.

Resources needed to mine and maintain data on the entire OSS code base and version histories far exceed what individual research groups can accomplish in the scope of conventional hypothesis-driven research. The pressing need to investigate the entirety of OSS will be addressed by creating requirements and building a community for an infrastructure that should contain: 1) A complete, rapidly updated source code data for the entirety of OSS; 2) Tooling for data correction, augmentation, and curation essential for such data: e.g., identity disambiguation and extraction of dependencies; 3) Services supporting research tasks that rely on the entirety of the collection; 4) A self-governing community of researchers, developers, and companies who maintain, enhance, and operate this infrastructure. To elicit the precise requirements for this OSS-wide infrastructure a wide audience of software researchers will be engaged.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Research in software engineering benefits tremendously from data. Our goal is to create a curated data source and analysis tools that will make it far simpler for researchers to do many of the kinds of empirical work that have become central to the field, and perhaps more importantly, make it possible to do research that requires all of the open source data in the world. The specific objectives of this planning grant were to create requirements and build a community for a software mining infrastructure containing: 1) A complete, rapidly updated source code data for the entirety of open source software (OSS); 2) Tooling for data correction, augmentation, and curation essential for such data: e.g., identity disambiguation and extraction of dependencies; 3) Services supporting research tasks that rely on the entirety of the collection, such as cross-referencing the data by individual developers, versions of the source code, the full graph of dependencies of the source code on external libraries or frameworks, and the capability to obtain stratified random samples of projects or developer; 4) A self-governing community of researchers, developers, and companies who maintain, enhance, and operate this infrastructure.

Through this project period, we have confirmed the existence of the user communities and the use cases through project activities and hackathons. Our sample use cases include bot detection, knowledge transfer between developers, adoption and reuse patterns of code snippets, identification of projects with unfixed vulnerabilities, determining different phases in software project evolution, and identification of individual contribution in OSS projects. We have created a set of prototype web applications at worldofcode.org that are based on the general RESTful API we developed to make use of large OSS data in support of such needs. We have also started and engaged in iterative cycles to use and continuously augment the RESTful API, as well as our prototype infrastructure.

We prepared and ran the first WoC hackathon Nov 1-3 at Carnegie Mellon University. Adapting to the strictures of the pandemic, we developed ways to adjust community-building activities to the no-travel environment, including a purely virtual second hackathon. We wrote a successful proposal for the virtual hackathon that has become a track at the International Symposium on Mining Software Repositories, 2021. That hackathon concluded successfully with 20 participants. We also have worked on implementing the findings of the first hackathon into the prototype of WoC infrastructure, and are currently doing the same for the results of the virtual hackathon, within the constraints of our very limited resources.  

We have gathered a diverse international Advisory Board with representatives from academia and industry and with key stakeholders who either are pursuing related objectives (Software Heritage, ghTorrent, BOA) or are likely to be the key users of the infrastructure.

In summary, as was the intent for this Planning Grant, we have everything in place, both technically and organizationally, to build a self-sustaining data resource that will be guided by the researchers whose work it will serve.
